and: Sorry. CVSDude shuffled repos around and I forgot to update docs
hsivonen: i changed the xpath stuff
looks
i had to actually learn about xpath and find something that would be a compromise between you and johnathan
so going by my track record, i (a) misunderstood xpath, and (b) wrote something neither of you like
Hixie: compromise in behavior or compromise in wording?
wording was my intent
Hixie: hmmkay. I *think* that's equivalent.
Hixie: I can live with that wording, although I think my wording was clearer
once i actually went and read xpath, i found both you and johnathan were proposing wording that didn't use the xpath 1.0 terminology.
Hixie: well, it's equivalent in WebKit and Opera. In Gecko, it will be equivalent after fixing another bug.
Hixie: OK. not surprising
(there's no "name expression" in xpath1, and "NameText" or whateven he was using was just a grammar production with no defined meaning as far as i could tell)
Hixie: thanks
np
hopefully he'll like it too
and: documentation fixed
and: and you can get just the htmlparser if you like: http://about.validator.nu/htmlparser/

hrm, on second reading I think this is a “major navigation block”, so nav is appropriate. nicely worded

google said it did at google i/o

Because, as much as people might like it to be something else, HTML5 has become the brand name for "cool cutting edge web technologies" in the same way that Ajax, XHTML and DHTML have been in the past
it's rather flaterring
flattering, even
wouldn't have happened if it was still called "Web Applications 1.0", i suppose
is baffled by this "accessibility task force" stuff
hard to say, back then we called it HTML5 too
Hixie, yeah, better becomes a really successful TF to be worth all this debating
why do we need a TF at all?
what is the TF for?
how can you even _have_ a TF for something as fundamental as accessibility?
it'd be like having a task force for performance
or a task force for making sure the spec is implementable in a multiprocess architecture
there's several WGs for accessibility so that certainly seems like something that's possible
the WGs for accessibility have done two things:
Hixie: as far as I can tell, the purpose of the TF is to put accessibility of HTML5 under WAI in the org chart
my assessment could be wrong, though
1. produced self-standing technologies or documentation, separate from anything else
2. commented on other specs
hsivonen, I think Sam Ruby said on the list it is that regardless of the whether the TF happens
hsivonen, something about the PFWG having to sign off anything we do before we go to LC
so i don't think the TF is comparable to the WGs, since a TF presumably wouldn't do either of those
annevk2: is the TF a telecon structure then?
i.e. people signed up for attending telecons?
hsivonen, I think it is the PFWG HTML5-subgroup that wants people from the HTML WG involved
hsivonen, but I might miss something, this has been going on for a while after all
i'm so tired of this "us vs them" nonsense
why can't they just participate in the wg's work like everyone else?
maybe I'm misunderstanding this all, but I don't like all the "mandate" and process stuff compared to just posting to public-html
I think the accessibility folks think they should have special veto powers above and beyond "normal" WG participants
jgraham: it sure looks like it
anyway, lunch time
And they want a process that will ensure that they get that
i guess i'll ask maciej about the accessibility tf tomorrow
and depending on what he says, i'll figure out what to do
participate, try to change the "charter", ignore them, try to get the tf killed, whatever
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MathML#Example is funny
and somewhat sad
Hixie, because the MathML example is 10 times longer than the other languages?
yeah
Funny as in "look how XML turns half a line of readable LaTeX into a screen full of unintelligable XML"
it's also an unfair comparison, the mathml is longer than it needs to be
it's sad how we ended up with an XML based format for maths, instead of simply a <math> element who's contents were interpreted as LaTeX and rendered appropriatley.
Lachy: I argued for that at the time but it is worth noting that "interpreted as LaTeX" isn't a well defined concept
Since TeX is a Turing-complete language
what we ended up with was the least bad of a bad bunch of options
as often has been the case in html5's development
I didn't know it was turing-complete
the continual race to suck the least we can
"HTML5: It could suck more"
I just know a lot of mathematicians actually use latex and it would have made sense to let them use it directly on the web
Yes
If you want to base it on usage, it would probably be better to use Microsoft Office's textual equation format
which exports to mathml
which is one reason we used mathml
We could have defined a subset of LaTeX and some magic to turn it into DOM. I admit this would not have been as conceptually simple as using MathML directly
But it would have been way easier to author
way easier to hand-author

jgraham: If you write a document in e.g. Word's equation editor, which has some textual format and is MathML internally, how would you export that to HTML when HTML requires a crazy syntax like LaTeX?
Parsing LaTeX is only half the problem
It's not obvious to me that going from MathML->LaTeX subset is a hard problem
especially if you design the subset with that in mind
ok if anyone is bored they can come up with examples for good tables that show off all html's table elements and attributes
in the meantime i'm gonna sleep
later
What if you e.g. make one of the variables in your equation red, using CSS?
(in the MathML representation)
Yeah that is a real problem
ALthough a rather uncommon one
To whom it may concern: a manual shouldn't read like a sales pitch
wonders what sales pitch jgraham is reading
So now there are complaints that HTML5 removes deprecated attributes from HTML4... isn't that the whole point of deprecation?
Dashiva, where?
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2009Sep/0450.html
tree builder flushes a text node before it is complete. a timeout appends another text node as the next sibling of the parser-inserted text node. Then the tree builder flushes the rest of the text.
http://html5doctor.com/the-section-element/
Which text node does the later tree builder flush go to?
Mercurial Queues are great. How do svn and cvs users manage without them?

Hixie: I had problems with bidirectional text a while back that I had to solve by explicitly inserting directionality characters.  Lemme dig up what the hell it was (it's obsolete now, so the example itself may be gone), so I can give you something for <bdo>.

Hixie: Ah, I remember now.  No clue why I was doing this, but I was editting a Hebrew text and adding inline English annotations.  Very annoying to deal with, and I didn't know <bdo> existed to help me.
hsivonen: Can you give me a really short summary of mq? I haven;t quite worked out if I should be using it all the time or if it is something that I can live without
jgraham: I regret postponing my starting of using it
jgraham: basically, you have a pushable and poppable queue of malleable hg revs
jgraham: that you can revise or pop
jgraham: then you can freeze the bottommost one to a real rev that you push when you get review
jgraham: so if your bottommost patch is being reviewed, you can already build on it but go back to address review comments
Interesting. Are there also advantages in review-free environments?
jgraham: I'm not aware of benefits in environments where you can commit a real rev before you start working on your next bug
jgraham: maybe hg 1.3 makes rebasing easier if you are rebasing an mq patch. dunno
hsivonen: Thnaks
*Thanks

oh, it's insane
just not as insane as trying to have two contradictory licences at once

So I'm sitting all up in #html, just minding my own business

[wito], great!

[wito], you do realize that none of the HTML versions you think should be handled in #html are actually going to survive for much longer?  Given that HTML5 is the only HTML version that actually has any resources being put into anymore?
I mean, all other HTML specs are obsolescent.
on versioning, please take another look at http://hsivonen.iki.fi/doctype/ie8-mode.png before wanting versioning
AryehGregor: obsolescent
that's an awsome word
But I disagree
A handy one too.
and XHTML 1.1 parsers are stable
So are HTML 1 parsers, I'm sure.
and will continue to benefit from improvements to SVG rendering engines
actually, XML 1.0 5Th edition just changed them
though fixes might not have been deployed to your favorite parser library just yet
AryehGregor, there was no HTML 1
Rats.
Foiled again.
it was called Tags, no?
and that's the glory of versioning
Well, I can fairly say that all HTML 1 parsers are stable, then.
there's an informal language that was developed prior to HTML 2.0 being published as RFC 1866 in 1995
basically, when you've got a version down; you freeze development, branch and have at the next version
[wito], XML 1.0 has no subversioning
(they're also all unstable, and made out of Swiss cheese, and so forth)
[wito], they changed parsing rules as "errata"
[wito], it was quite controversial
[wito], or you could just make sure everything is backwards-compatible and not need versioning.
annevk2: I'm sorry, whatnow?
[wito], see w3.org/tr/xml
AryehGregor: Except for the fact that this will keep you back later
Which is what HTML5 does.
backwards-compatible is a dream
[wito], how will it ?
[wito], it will keep you back less than pretending you don't need to be completely backward compatible, which is what XHTML 2 did.
and in *my* programming experience, it's not always a good thing
much like versioning on the Web
sometimes, you just need to go forward
[wito], it's not a good thing.  It's inevitable on the web, however.
backwards compatible is a necessary reaslity for the web
*reality
You can't fix up all the content out there.
use the XML serialization, use namespaces. voila.
That's just fact.
AryehGregor: Which is where versioning comes into play
Except then users can't use the new features without rewriting their site.
Which few will do.

*versioned

everyone is free to use the old version if they want
anyway

I didn't come here to discuss versioning
